question: Question_05_(b)
statement:
\emph{A person purchased a home at the price of \$ 300,000, paid a down
payment equal to 20\% of the purchase price, and financed the remaining
balance with a 25 year term mortgage. Assume that the person makes
payments continuously at a constant annual rate $A$ and that the
interest is compounded continuously at the rate of 5\%.}

Determine \emph{A}, the rate of annual payments that is required to pay
off the loan in 25 years.
sols:
From
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH105/April 2010/Question 5 (a)}{part
(a)} we have that

\begin{align*}\frac{\textrm{d}y}{\textrm{d}t}=0.05y(t)-A\end{align*}

with the initial amount of money owed being $y(0)=240 000$. The goal is
to solve this equation for the rate of $y$ so that we can actually
obtain the quantity we want, $y(t)$ which is the money owed after $t$
years. Consider the substitution,

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}u(t)=0.05y-A\end{align*}

which implies that

\begin{align*}\frac{\textrm{d}u}{\textrm{d}t}=0.05\frac{\textrm{d}y}{\textrm{d}t}.\end{align*}

Therefore we can rewrite (and simplify) our differential equation as

\begin{align*}\frac{\textrm{d}u}{\textrm{d}t}=ru\end{align*}

which we recognize as the exponential model and so we know the solution
is

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}u(t)=B\exp(0.05t)\end{align*}

with $B$ an arbitrary constant. This solution can also be determined
from separation of variables and integration. Putting back into our
original variable, $y(t)$, we get

\begin{align*}y(t)=\frac{B\exp(0.05t)+A}{0.05}.\end{align*}

which is our desired equation for the amount owed on the mortgage after
time $t$. Using the initial condition

\begin{align*}y(0)=\frac{B+A}{0.05}=240 000\end{align*}

we get that $B=12000-A$. Therefore we are able to write the amount of
money owed solely in terms of the annual payments, $A$,

\begin{align*}y(t)=\frac{(12000-A)\exp(0.05t)+A}{0.05}.\end{align*}

Now when $t=25$, we want that the mortgage is paid off, i.e., we want
the amount of money we owe to be zero. Therefore we seek that $y(25)=0$.
Therefore,

\begin{align*}
0&=\frac{(12000-A)\exp(0.05 \cdot 25)}{0.05}\\
A&=\frac{12000\exp(0.05 \cdot 25)}{\exp(0.05 \cdot 25)-1}=16818.61.\end{align*}

Therefore, in order to pay off the mortgage in 25 years, we require that
$A$ = 16818.61. Recall that when we started paying the mortgage at year
zero we owed 80\% of the value or 240 000 dollars. If we want to find
out how much we really paid, we just need to multiply our annual rate,
$A$ by 25 years to get \$420 465.25. Add this to the \$60 000 we already
paid up front then our \$300 000 dollar house has actually cost us \$480
465.25!
hints:
We have a differential equation to model the \textbf{rate} of the amount
of money. What techniques do we have to turn that rate,

\begin{align*}\frac{\textrm{d}y}{\textrm{d}t}\end{align*} into the actual amount of money left
owed, $y(t)$?

How can you use separation of variables to write your differential
equation in terms of some integrals that you know how to evaluate?
